    <item>
      <title>Michael Temer takes reins as Brazil's president with pledge to rebuild country</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/michel-temer-brazil-president-rebuild-impeachment</link>
      <description><p>Dilma Rousseff’s suspension in impeachment vote hands power to ex-deputy who has promised unity while installing all-male, conspicuously white cabinet</p><p>Brazil’s interim president, Michel Temer, has unveiled an all-male, conspicuously white cabinet to run one of the world’s most ethnically diverse nations as he promised to restore confidence in Latin America’s biggest economy.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/the-guardian-view-on-dilma-rousseffs-impeachment-the-political-system-should-be-on-trial-not-one-woman">The Guardian view on Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment: the political system should be on trial, not one woman | Editorial</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/michel-temer-brazil-president-rebuild-impeachment">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'No injustice is more devastating': Dilma Rousseff condemns rivals' 'treachery'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/dilma-rousseff-brazil-impeachment-vows-fight</link>
      <description><p>Impeachment defeat not the end of suspended president’s fight as she will go on trial for up to six months on charges of doctoring government accounts</p><p>There were no tears – at least not from Dilma Rousseff – as she left the Planalto presidential palace after an impeachment defeat that curtails 13 years of Workers’ party rule in Brazil and may well end the political career of the country’s first female president.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/09/dilma-rousseff-brazil-impeachment-fight-congress-vote">A warrior to the end: Dilma Rousseff a sinner and saint in impeachment fight</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/dilma-rousseff-brazil-impeachment-vows-fight">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Facebook news selection is in hands of editors not algorithms, documents show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-trending-news-leaked-documents-editor-guidelines</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> Leaked internal guidelines show human intervention at almost every stage of its news operation, akin to a traditional media organization</p><p>Leaked documents show how Facebook, now the biggest news distributor on the planet, relies on old-fashioned news values on top of its algorithms to determine what the hottest stories will be for the 1 billion people who visit the social network every day.</p><p>The documents, given to the Guardian, come amid growing concerns over how Facebook decides what is news for its users. This week the company was accused of an <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/facebook-newsfeed-censor-conservative-news">editorial bias against conservative news organizations</a>, prompting <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/facebook-trending-conservative-news-senate-committee-letter">calls for a congressional inquiry</a> from the US Senate commerce committee chair, John Thune.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-trending-news-leaked-documents-editor-guidelines">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Some US states fall short on tax transparency, says Cameron</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/tax-transparency-efforts-fail-american-states-excluded-summit</link>
      <description><p>Prime minister casts doubt on whether United States can be part of ‘coalition of the committed’ against corruption</p><p>David Cameron has cast doubt on whether the United States could be truly considered part of a coalition committed to the fight against corruption, saying some US states fall far short on tax transparency and are less open than the UK’s crown dependencies.</p><p>The prime minister made his remarks at the close of a corruption summit in London that brought together more than 40 countries, including the US, in an attempt to fight corruption, restore stolen assets and toughen laws to fight evasion.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/tax-transparency-efforts-fail-american-states-excluded-summit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Walkout at Ugandan president's inauguration over ICC remarks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/walkout-at-ugandan-presidents-inauguration-over-icc-remarks</link>
      <description><p>US, Canadian and European diplomats protest after Yoweri Museveni says international criminal court is ‘a bunch of useless people’</p><p>Delegates from North America and Europe who were attending t<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/uganda-president-yoweri-museveni-sworn-in-fifth-term">he inauguration of the Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni</a>, have walked out of the ceremony in protest against his comments about the international criminal court (ICC) in The Hague, and the presence of Sudan’s leader, whom the court has indicted.</p><p>Elizabeth Trudeau, a spokeswoman for the US state department, said the US ambassador to Uganda, Deborah Malac, and a visiting Washington-based official, along with several European and Canadian diplomats, abruptly left the inauguration on Thursday after Museveni made negative remarks about the ICC in his inaugural address. She said that the US also objected to the participation in the inauguration of the Sudanese president, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/15/south-africa-to-fight-omar-al-bashirs-arrest-warrant-sudan">Omar al-Bashir</a>. Bashir has been charged by the court for atrocities in Sudan’s western region Darfur.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/walkout-at-ugandan-presidents-inauguration-over-icc-remarks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Zika virus makes Rio Olympics a threat in Brazil and abroad, health expert says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/rio-olympics-zika-amir-attaran-public-health-threat</link>
      <description><p>Amir Attaran calls for postponement or moving of Games and says biggest risk is spreading the virus to countries without adequate healthcare infrastructure </p><p>As Brazil reels from a spiraling political crisis and its deepest recession in decades, a public health specialist in Canada has added to the country’s woes with a high-profile call for the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/olympic-games-2016">2016 summer Olympics</a> – slated to kick off in Rio de Janeiro in early August – to be postponed or moved due to the Zika outbreak.<br></p><p>“But for the Games, would anyone recommend sending an extra half a million visitors into Brazil right now?” Canadian professor Amir Attaran, whose research areas include population health and global development policy, asked this week in a commentary <a href="http://harvardpublichealthreview.org/off-the-podium-why-rios-2016-olympic-games-must-not-proceed/#_edn5">published in the Harvard Public Health Review</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/rio-olympics-zika-amir-attaran-public-health-threat">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Red Cross aid convoy denied entry to Syrian city of Darayya</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/red-cross-convoy-denied-entery-to-syrian-city-of-darayya</link>
      <description><p>Five-truck convoy was not allowed to deliver nutrition items for children and vaccines to besieged city</p><p>An aid convoy has been refused entry to the besieged Syrian city of Darayya , the Red Cross said, dashing hopes for the first such delivery since regime forces surrounded the rebel-held town in 2012.</p><p>Meanwhile, a truce in Aleppo has expired with no new last-minute prolongation after it had been extended twice through last-minute intervention by Moscow and Washington. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/red-cross-convoy-denied-entery-to-syrian-city-of-darayya">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ex-Deutsche Bank executive given four-and-a-half years for insider trading</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/ex-deutsche-bank-boss-martyn-dodgson-four-and-a-half-years-for-insider-trading</link>
      <description><p>Martyn Dodgson and ex-finance director Andrew Hind jailed for making deals on stock markets using classified information </p><p>A former Deutsche Bank managing director and an accountant have been sent to prison for “persistent, prolonged, deliberate, dishonest behaviour”, drawing a line under the UK financial watchdog’s eight-and-a-half year insider dealing inquiry.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/painstaking-investigation-deutsche-bank-insider-trading">Martyn Dodgson</a>, a 44-year-old financier who advised the government during the financial crisis, was sentenced to four-and-a-half years on Thursday for his part in an elaborate scam that prosecutors said made more than £6.9m between 2006 and 2010. It is the longest UK prison term handed down for the crime. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/ex-deutsche-bank-boss-martyn-dodgson-four-and-a-half-years-for-insider-trading">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Trump and Ryan: meeting was a 'very positive step' toward GOP unity – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/us-election-live-trump-paul-ryan-meeting</link>
      <description><ul><li>Presumptive nominee and congressional leaders meet on Capitol Hill</li><li>‘I want to be part of the unifying process,’ House speaker has said</li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/moderate-republicans-donald-trump-hillary-clinton">Take it or leave it: Trump’s rise puts GOP moderates in tough corner</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers">Saudi officials were supporting 9/11 hijackers, commission member says</a></li></ul><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:25:12.656Z">3.25am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Can’t we all just get along?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:11:35.565Z">3.11am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to “invit[e] leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Zuckerberg invites top conservatives to talk and denies Facebook bias</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/us-election-live-trump-paul-ryan-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/egypts-activists-social-media-facebook-satirists-release-awlad-el-shawarea</link>
      <description><p>Clips uploaded to Facebook featured activists demanding the release of members of group Awlad el-Shawarea</p><p>Egyptian activists are using social media to demand the release of five detained members of a satirical street performance group whose video clips mocked the president, Abdel Fatah al-Sisi.</p><p>The activists posted pictures on Facebook of themselves holding mobile phones in front of their faces with the caption: “Does a mobile phone camera rattle you?”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/egypts-activists-social-media-facebook-satirists-release-awlad-el-shawarea">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>George Zimmerman's gun used to kill Trayvon Martin back up for auction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/george-zimmerman-gun-trayvon-martin-gun-auction-website-removed</link>
      <description><p>Handgun, which Zimmerman calls a ‘piece of American history’, reappears on firearms site after it was pulled from GunBroker.com amid widespread criticism</p><p>An attempt by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/george-zimmerman">George Zimmerman</a> to auction the gun he used to kill Trayvon Martin in 2012 appeared to be back on again Thursday following an extraordinary day in which the owner of the first website on which the weapon first appeared took down the listing, saying he wanted no part of the controversial sale.</p><p>Billed as “your opportunity to own a piece of American history”, Zimmerman’s listing abruptly disappeared from GunBroker.com shortly after the auction’s advertised 11am ET start time. The former neighbourhood watch volunteer, who was acquitted three years ago over the death of the unarmed black teenager in Sanford, Florida – a case that sparked protests and a national debate about race relations – was seeking at least $5,000 for the gun.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/george-zimmerman-gun-trayvon-martin-gun-auction-website-removed">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/indian-doctors-ivf-woman-70s-gives-birth-fertility-treatment-daljinder-kaur</link>
      <description><p>Doctors call for upper age limit for fertility treatment after Daljinder Kaur has first child after 46 years of marriage</p><p>Doctors in India have raised concerns about IVF treatment in the country, after a couple in their 70s had their first child after 46 years of marriage.     <item>
      <title>Secret area of Guantánamo could be opened to UN watchdog for first time</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/guantanamo-camp-7-torture-ammar-al-baluchi-un</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> Attorneys for alleged 9/11 co-conspirator request UN access to Camp 7 to prevent evidence they say was coerced during torture being used against him</p><p>The most secret corner of Guantánamo Bay could be opened up to the UN torture watchdog for the first time, if an audacious legal gambit succeeds.</p><p>Attorneys for Ammar al-Baluchi, one of the accused 9/11 co-conspirators facing a military tribunal at Guantánamo Bay, will request on Thursday that the judge in the case order access to Guantánamo’s Camp 7 – where he and other detainees formerly in brutal CIA custody reside practically incommunicado – for Juan Mendez, the UN’s special rapporteur on torture.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/guantanamo-camp-7-torture-ammar-al-baluchi-un">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Russia launches first rocket from new spaceport</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/spacewatch-russia-launches-new-spaceport</link>
      <description><p>Russia has launched the first rocket from its new spaceport. Although not yet finished, the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2016/apr/28/putin-watches-first-rocket-launch-from-new-vosochny-cosmodrome-video">Vostochny cosmodrome</a> has cost £2bn and taken five years to build so far. When completed in the 2020s, it will launch cosmonauts and <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/09/russia-launches-first-space-rocket-soviet-era">Russia’s new Angara rocket</a>, which could eventually take people to the moon.</p><p>The spaceport became operational on 28 April when a <a draggable="true" href="http://spaceflight101.com/spacerockets/soyuz-2-1v/">Soyuz-2.1 rocket</a> lifted off carrying three satellites into orbit. Vladimir Putin attended the launch and had words of both congratulation and warning.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/spacewatch-russia-launches-new-spaceport">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Lawyer for Hakim Nasiri says his client is innocent, while two other men arrested in connection with case remain in custody</p><p>An Italian judge has ordered the release of a terror suspect who was alleged to have scoped targets in the UK and Italy and whose arrest was hailed as a sign of Italy’s effective counter-terrorism programme.</p><p>The decision to release Hakim Nasiri, a 23-year-old Afghan, was not formally explained by the presiding judge, Francesco Agnino.       <title>South African musicians hail end of 'cultural imperialism' on radio</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/south-african-musicians-hail-end-of-cultural-imperialism-with-radio-quota</link>
      <description><p>National broadcaster SABC announces that 90% of music played on its 18 radio stations will be from local artists</p><p>South African musicians have joyfully welcomed an announcement that their music will dominate the country’s airwaves after years of “cultural imperialism”.<br></p><p>The national broadcaster, <a href="http://www.sabc.co.za/wps/portal/SABC/SABCHOME">SABC</a>, decided this week that 90% of the music played on its radio stations would be by local artists, a move that one of South Africa’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/dec/25/the-playlist-the-best-south-african-hip-hop-of-2014-with-tumi-and-aka">hip-hop</a> stars compared to Nelson Mandela’s release from prison.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/south-african-musicians-hail-end-of-cultural-imperialism-with-radio-quota">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>US and UK urge banks to do business with Iran</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran</link>
      <description><p>Iranian president Hassan Rouhani is under pressure from hardliners as lifting of sanctions fails to live up to expectations</p><p>An attempt by the US and UK governments to persuade European banks to do more business in Iran in the wake of last year’s nuclear deal, appears to have fallen on deaf ears.</p><p>Senior representatives from nine major banks listened on Thursday to appeals from the US secretary of state, John Kerry, and the British foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, urging them to help finance expanded trade with Iran following the lifting of sanctions under the agreement sealed in Vienna last July. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Saudi officials were 'supporting' 9/11 hijackers, commission member says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers</link>
      <description><p>First serious public split revealed among commissioners over the release of the secret ‘28 pages’ that detail Saudi ties to 2001 terrorist attacks </p><p>A former Republican member of the 9/11 commission, breaking dramatically with the commission’s leaders, said Wednesday he believes there was clear evidence that Saudi government employees were part of a support network for the 9/11 hijackers and that the Obama administration should move quickly to declassify a long-secret congressional report on Saudi ties to the 2001 terrorist attack.</p><p> The comments by John F Lehman, an investment banker in New York who was Navy secretary in the Reagan administration, signal the first serious public split among the 10 commissioners since they issued a 2004 final report that was largely read as an exoneration of Saudi Arabia, which was home to 15 of the 19 hijackers on 9/11.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>French financial prosecutors confirm investigation into Tokyo 2020 bid</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/french-financial-prosecutors-confirm-investigation-into-tokyo-2020-bid-olympics-black-tidings</link>
      <description>• Officials to look into payments made to Black Tidings account<br />• Tokyo’s Olympic organising committee denies wrongdoing<p>French financial prosecutors have confirmed they are investigating allegations of “corruption and money laundering” involving more than $2m in suspicious payments apparently made by the Tokyo 2020 Olympic bid to a secret bank account linked to the son of disgraced former world athletics chief Lamine Diack.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/tokyo-olympics-payment-diack-2020-games" title="">The Guardian revealed on Wednesday</a> that payments totalling at least $1.5m had apparently been made to the Black Tidings company that was at the centre of other allegations of extortion and bribery linked to the International Association of Athletics Federations. Now, French prosecutors have confirmed they are investigating payments totalling 2.8m Singapore dollars that were made under the title “Tokyo 2020 Olympic Game bid” either side of Tokyo’s successful bid to host the Games in September 2013.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/french-financial-prosecutors-confirm-investigation-into-tokyo-2020-bid-olympics-black-tidings">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>US poultry workers wear diapers on job over lack of bathroom breaks – report</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/poultry-workers-wear-diapers-work-bathroom-breaks</link>
      <description><ul><li>Oxfam says many are afraid to ask for permission to go to the bathroom<br></li><li>One supplier calls allegations ‘troubling’ and refusal of breaks not tolerated<br></li></ul><p>A <a href="https://www.oxfamamerica.org/static/media/files/No_Relief_Embargo.pdf">report</a> from international advocacy group Oxfam says poultry workers in the United States labor in a “climate of fear”, with some forced to wear diapers on the job. </p><p> It says many workers are afraid to ask for permission to go to the bathroom. The report says a worker at a Simmons Foods plant in Arkansas told Oxfam that she and many others resorted to wearing diapers. A Tyson Foods worker says in the report that many workers at his North Carolina plant “have to urinate in their pants”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/poultry-workers-wear-diapers-work-bathroom-breaks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities</link>
      <description><p>Outdoor pollution has risen 8% in five years with fast-growing cities in the developing world worst affected, WHO data shows</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Air pollution: how does it affect you?</a><br></li></ul><p><br>Outdoor air pollution has grown 8% globally in the past five years, with billions of people around the world now exposed to dangerous air, <a href="http://www.who.int/phe">according to new data</a> from more than 3,000 cities compiled by the World Health Organisation (WHO). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Kremlin angered as US switches on missile shield in Romania</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-hails-important-step-as-missile-defences-go-live-in-romania</link>
      <description><p>Russia believes shield is intended to weaken its nuclear capabilities, which US officials insist is not the case</p><p>The US has switched on a missile shield in Romania that it sees as vital to defending itself and Europe from long-range missiles fired by rogue states, prompting anger from the Kremlin which believes the shield’s main goal is to weaken its own strategic nuclear capabilities.<br></p><p>The eventual missile shield will stretch from Greenland to the Azores, and will be ready by the end of 2018. On Friday, the US will break ground on a final site in Poland. The proposal was first agreed by the administration of George W Bush a decade ago and is a longstanding gripe for Moscow, despite repeated assurances from Washington that it is not aimed against Russia.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-hails-important-step-as-missile-defences-go-live-in-romania">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>WHO recommends shorter drug regimen for multi-drug resistant TB</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/shorter-treatment-multi-drug-resistant-tb-raises-hopes-who</link>
      <description><p>New diagnostic test and nine-month course of treatment may help save thousands of lives, health body says<br></p><p>A new drug regime that shortens the treatment for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis from two years to nine months has been recommended for use by the World Health Organisation, raising hopes that hundreds of thousands of people will stay the course and be cured.</p><p>About 480,000 people are estimated by the WHO to have this form of the infectious disease, which has been found in every country in the world and kills 190,000 every year. MDR-TB cannot be cured by the standard six-month regimen of antibiotics because the bacteria have become resistant to some or all of the drugs, meaning they no longer work.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/shorter-treatment-multi-drug-resistant-tb-raises-hopes-who">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>MH370: two new aircraft fragments 'almost certainly' from missing aircraft</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/mh370-two-new-aircraft-fragments-almost-certainly-from-missing-plane</link>
      <description><p>Australian announcement about pieces found in South Africa and Mauritius means a total of five pieces of debris have now been confirmed from missing jet</p><p>Two aircraft fragments found on the beaches of South Africa and Mauritius are all but confirmed to be from missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which mysteriously disappeared two years ago with 239 people on board. </p><p>A piece of engine cowling featuring a Rolls-Royce stencil, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/23/possible-piece-of-mh370-engine-found-on-south-african-beach">which was found in South Africa earlier this year</a>, is “almost certainly” from the Boeing 777 that went missing more than two years ago with 239 people on board, the Australian Transport Safety Bureau said on Thursday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/mh370-two-new-aircraft-fragments-almost-certainly-from-missing-plane">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Great Barrier Reef: devastating images tell story of coral colonies' destruction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-devastating-images-tell-story-of-coral-colonies-destruction</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> a series of images taken from around Lizard Island reveal the rapid death of coral across thousands of kilometres of the reef as bleaching takes hold</p><p>Devastating images showing the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/19/great-barrier-reef-93-of-reefs-hit-by-coral-bleaching">complete destruction of coral colonies on the Great Barrier Reef</a> have been obtained by Guardian Australia and illustrate what is happening to coral there that would fill an area the size of Scotland.</p><p>They reveal the rapid death of coral impacting much of the Great Barrier Reef, with estimates that as much as half of the coral in the northern third of the 2000km reef had this fate.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-devastating-images-tell-story-of-coral-colonies-destruction">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Unprecedented 'red tide' crisis deepens in Chile's fishing-rich waters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/red-tide-crisis-deepens-in-chile-fishing-waters</link>
      <description><p>The ‘<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/03/chile-fishermen-red-tide-algal-bloom-protests">red tide</a>’ algal bloom, which turns the sea water red and makes seafood toxic, is believed to be one of the country’s worst recent environmental crises </p><p>A “red tide” outbreak is widening in southern Chile’s fishing-rich waters, the government has said, deepening what is already believed to be one of the country’s worst environmental crises in recent years.</p><p> The red tide – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/03/chile-fishermen-red-tide-algal-bloom-protests">an algal bloom that turns the seawater red and makes seafood toxic</a> – is a common, naturally recurring phenomenon in southern Chile, but the extent of the current outbreak is unprecedented.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/red-tide-crisis-deepens-in-chile-fishing-waters">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Story of cities #42: Medellín escapes grip of drug lord to embrace radical urbanism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/13/story-cities-pablo-escobar-inclusive-urbanism-medellin-colombia</link>
      <description><p>Twenty-five years ago, Medellín was the most dangerous city on earth. Yet its most infamous criminal, Pablo Escobar, also helped create the conditions that sparked an extraordinary revival – by taking the city to the brink of collapse </p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/series/the-story-of-cities">Read more articles in the series here</a></li></ul><p>“I’d never been to that neighbourhood before. It was a new world to me.” The architect Luis Miguel Velez Wiesner is recalling the first time he set foot in Santo Domingo, one of Colombia’s most notorious favelas, when the Medellín cable car opened in 2004. “The first time, I felt like I was going to be kidnapped. Now it’s quite different – there are lots of places to eat and shop. It feels safe now.”</p><p>For intrepid residents such as Wiesner, stepping off the cable car to enter the once out of bounds “other side” of Medellín, was a seminal moment in the history of their city.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/13/story-cities-pablo-escobar-inclusive-urbanism-medellin-colombia">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>We often know when drought or floods will strike. So let's act before they do | Neil Marsland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/el-nino-farmers-frontline-drought-floods-building-resilience</link>
      <description><p>Climate change and the current strong El Niño are creating costly humanitarian crises. But it’s so much cheaper to avert disaster through building resilience</p><p>The life of a farmer in Somalia is never easy and, right now, it’s about as hard as it gets. The weather <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/nov/23/somaliland-climate-change-drought-cyclones-life-or-death-challenge">no longer seems to follow recognisable patterns</a> and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/16/drought-high-temperatures-el-nino-36m-people-africa-hunger">El Niño phenomenon</a> is exacerbating the crisis.</p><p>At 47 years old, Maymuno Madobe Cali has seen it all: drought, floods, disease and conflict. She knows only too well how a precious but fragile livelihood can vanish. She lost 26 goats the last time floods and water-borne diseases came to Boodaale and she is praying the same will not happen to her remaining 11 animals. With seven people in her family, another spell of bad weather could push her to the brink. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/el-nino-farmers-frontline-drought-floods-building-resilience">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Financial jolt triggered by departure could lead to key industries suffering same fate as coal mining, says Patrick McLoughlin</p><p>Farming and the car industry could disappear from Britain like coal mining in the 1980s because of the financial shock of leaving the EU, Patrick McLoughlin, the transport secretary, has warned.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">Brexit could lead to recession, says Bank of England</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/13/brexit-eu-referendum-farming-car-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/foreign-agent-law-shot-down-by-kyrgyzstan-parliament</link>
      <description><p>In a surprise result, MPs vote against bill to restrict charities who receive funding from abroad. <a href="http://www.eurasianet.org/node/78756">Eurasianet.org</a> reports</p><p>Kyrgyzstan’s parliament has voted against a contentious “foreign agent” bill which would have enforced <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/26/harassed-and-shunned-the-russians-labelled-foreign-agents-by-kremlin">harsh restrictions on groups</a> who receive donations from abroad. </p><p>In a surprise move, 65 of the 111 members of parliament present voted against the proposed legislation, which was undergoing its final reading.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/foreign-agent-law-shot-down-by-kyrgyzstan-parliament">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/little-obama-jokes-soviet-era-racism-remains-alive-in-russia</link>

      <description><p>Subverting stereotypes in new campaign, players tell <a href="http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-05-11-jozi-cats-africas-first-gay-rugby-club-has-an-important-role-to-play-in-sa/">the Daily Maverick</a> they’ve been overwhelmed by the positive response</p><p>Africa’s <a href="https://www.gaytimes.co.uk/news/35669/africas-first-gay-rugby-team-fights-stereotypes-bold-campaign/">first gay and inclusive rugby club</a> has launched a provocative campaign featuring homophobic slurs in a bid undermine stereotypes. </p><p>The new recruitment drive features posters of team members accompanied by words such as “queen”, “fairy” and “pansy”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/africa-first-gay-rugby-club-jozi-cats-gay-lgbt-stereotypes">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/kenya-dadaab-closure-refugees-caught-up-in-cynical-electioneering</link>
      <description><p>Plan to close the world’s largest camp is illogical and illegal – but scores much-needed political points, argues <a href="http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-05-09-collateral-damage-the-refugees-caught-up-in-kenyas-cynical-electioneering#.VzHuIBUrJpQ">the Daily Maverick</a></p><p>The Kenyan government <a href="http://www.voanews.com/content/kenya-moves-to-close-refugee-camps-holding-400-thousand/3318649.html">has announced</a> that it will attempt to close all of the country’s refugee camps, a move that could displace an estimated 600,000 vulnerable people.</p><p>However, it’s no coincidence that just a week before the statement the Kenyan president Uhuru Kenyatta officially <a href="http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-04-19-kenya-kenyatta-kicks-off-2017-campaign-with-the-icc-still-in-his-crosshairs/">began campaigning</a> ahead of elections scheduled for next year.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/kenya-dadaab-closure-refugees-caught-up-in-cynical-electioneering">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>In from the cold: Iran x Cuba – review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2016/may/10/iran-x-cuba-beyond-the-headline-review</link>
      <description><p>Playful seriousness abounds in this exhibition at New York’s Rogue Space gallery</p><p>Holy Cow. The title of Allahyar Najafi’s painting captures the playful seriousness that abounds in IRAN X CUBA: Beyond the Headline. The show features work by 19 artists from two countries whose revolutions denied them the tender affections of a certain global hegemon for decades on end; now, as if love might actually trump hate in time, they have come together at New York’s Rogue Space gallery. <br></p><p>In Najafi’s piece, the titular bovine, sacred not only in Hinduism – the artist resided in India for several years – but in Iran’s own Zoroastrianism, weeps amid an array of other hallowed beasts. Through the ether swim a pod of Caspian seals, seemingly a personal totem for the artist, who now lives in Rasht, not far from the sea (one takes center stage in Pusa Caspica, after the animal’s Latin name). From a crook in the cow’s form stares a bald eagle, once-secular American iconography now as sanctified as the almighty dollar.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2016/may/10/iran-x-cuba-beyond-the-headline-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Massive water transfer schemes are no solution to Iran’s growing problems with drought<br></p><p>A grand vision of eliminating water scarcity looks attractive for tens of millions of people in the desert cities of central Iran worried about drought. Ambitious water transfer projects are being put in place to answer <a href="http://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/‌2016/‌ 03/‌08/‌1022552/water-to-be-transferred-from-persian-gulf-to-central-iran-in-giant-project">a call</a> from President Hassan Rouhani. <br></p><p>Two high-profile projects would see desalinised water transferred to the central plateau from the <a href="http://financialtribune.com/articles/environment/39621/new-twist-caspian-water-transfer-debate">Caspian Sea</a>, and from the <a href="http://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2016/03/08/1022552/water-to-be-transferred-from-persian-gulf-to-central-iran-in-giant-project">Persian Gulf and Sea of Oman</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/09/iran-desalination-water">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/13/marshall-marcus-the-european-union-youth-orchestra-cannot-be-strangled</link>
      <description><p>The EUYO has announced its closure. Chief Executive Marshall Marcus explains why a 40-year-old institution that represents the best of pan-European creativity has been silenced</p><p>Amid the sagging plethora of Brexit conversations, real passion can often seem to be lacking among the EU’s top brass. Except however, when they talk about one particular enterprise: “<a href="http://www.euyo.eu/">The European Union Youth Orchestra</a> remains one of our most distinguished ambassadors … a potent symbol of our European Union.” (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/jean-claude-juncker">Jean-Claude Juncker</a>, EU Commission President). <br></p><p>“I was moved not simply by the beauty of the music they produced, but also by what they stand for: the EUYO perfectly embodies the power of being united in diversity,” (Juncker’s colleague <a href="http://www.europarl.europa.eu/the-president/en/">Martin Schulz</a>, European Parliament President). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/13/marshall-marcus-the-european-union-youth-orchestra-cannot-be-strangled">Continue reading...</a></description>

And every report features the intriguing character of Mohammed bin Salman, the deputy crown prince and rising star of an increasingly unpredictable kingdom.</p><p>Bin Salman, an imposing man of 30, oversees a team of advisers and ministers who are working on the grandiosely named<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/25/saudi-arabia-approves-ambitious-plan-to-move-economy-beyond-oil"> Vision 2030 </a>– designed to prepare pampered Saudis for a life after oil by diversifying, privatising and modernising the largest economy in the Arab world.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/mohammed-bin-salman-the-prince-trying-to-ween-saudi-arabia-off-oil">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Baby unable to breathe without aid when flown off the island with Somali mother en route to Australia, immigration department says </p><p>A 22-year-old Somali refugee and her newborn baby have been medically evacuated from Nauru after she underwent a caesarean section a month prematurely.</p><p>The immigration department confirmed the woman and her baby had been transferred to Australia where they were receiving “appropriate medical treatment”, but declined to comment further. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/nauru-refugee-and-premature-baby-in-critical-condition-after-emergency-caesarean">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The blast, which also wounded 17, occurred when the bombmakers were unloading the device, authorities said</p><p>Four suspected bombmakers have been killed and 17 people wounded after an explosion ripped through a village in Turkey’s mainly Kurdish south-east, security sources and the interior ministry said.<br></p><p> The blast occurred on Thursday night in the Sarikamis district, about 25km (15 miles) from the city of Diyarbakir, as alleged Kurdistan Workers party (PKK) militants loaded explosives on to a small truck, according to the ministry.       <description><p>Estate agent predicts some billionaire clients will sell property if no longer able to keep identity secret via offshore firms<br></p><p>Super-rich international investors in London property are likely to sell off some of their mansions and penthouses after the introduction of anti-corruption rules cracking down on offshore secrecy, a leading estate agent has said.</p><p>Privacy-hungry oligarchs, media owners and tech billionaires from around the world could also abandon plans to buy homes in Britain because they would no longer be able to keep their identity secret by purchasing them through offshore companies, Trevor Abrahmsohn told the Guardian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/super-rich-may-sell-london-homes-under-anti-corruption-rules">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What’s at stake in the EU-US trade deal talks | Letters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/whats-at-stake-in-the-eu-us-trade-deal-talks</link>
      <description><p>It is true, as Owen Jones suggests (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/05/protest-never-changes-anything-derailing-ttip-trade-agreement" title="">Protest never changes anything?</a>, 5 May), that the credibility of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership EU-US trade deal has taken a battering because of concerted public pressure. But this is no time for complacency. Off&nbsp;the record, civil servants at the European commission will tell you they are relaxed about TTIP hitting the buffers because negotiations on the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement with Canada have been completed and await European parliament approval.</p><p>In terms of transferring power from countries to corporations, the CETA is every bit as bad as TTIP and contains a version of the thoroughly discredited investor state dispute settlement mechanism that allows big companies to sue governments in parallel courts if their rent-seeking activities are curtailed by legislation protecting public services.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/whats-at-stake-in-the-eu-us-trade-deal-talks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How history shaped Jewish identity | Letters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/how-history-shaped-jewish-identity</link>
      <description><p>Your correspondents seeking to defend the Labour party from allegations of antisemitism disgrace themselves and their argument when they claim that “most Jews who perished in the Holocaust were indifferent to Zionism and many opposed it” (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/anti-zionism-does-not-equate-to-antisemitism" title="">Letters</a>, 11&nbsp;May).</p><p>They simply do not know what the 6&nbsp;million victims of Nazi antisemitism thought of Zionism. They do not know how many Polish Jews who voted for non-Zionist parties before the war changed their views as they were forced into ghettos and camps, starved&nbsp;and worked to death, shot into pits and herded into gas chambers. They do not know how many Jews might have been saved had Israel existed in the 1930s, nor how many survivors were grateful for Zionism after the war when Israel was the only country that would take them in.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/how-history-shaped-jewish-identity">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Welcome, Lord Prime Minister: Cambodian media told to use leader's full royal title</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/cambodian-media-prime-minister-hun-sen-full-royal-title</link>
      <description><p>Print, radio and TV organisations told to use Hun Sen’s honorary six-word title in opening lines of all stories about him or face legal action</p><p>For years, some Cambodian media have referred to the country’s longtime leader as Prime Minister Hun Sen – but, as of Thursday, authorities have warned that this must stop.<br></p><p>Starting in August, all media must use his full, honorary, six-word title – “Samdech Akka Moha Sena Padei Techo Hun Sen” – in the opening lines of print articles, radio and TV stories about him. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/cambodian-media-prime-minister-hun-sen-full-royal-title">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/childrens-services-call-for-resources-to-deal-with-rise-in-child-refugees</link>
      <description><p>UK council leaders welcome government decision to take in more lone refugee children but say they need extra resources</p><p>Council leaders, children’s services and foster carer networks have called on the government to properly resource local authorities to cope with the expected rise in unaccompanied child asylum seekers entering Britain.<br></p><p>They have warned that existing funding is inadequate to meet the needs of often traumatised children fleeing conflict zones and have voiced concerns over the government’s failure so far to provide details of how children arriving alone will be assessed and transferred to different parts of the country.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/childrens-services-call-for-resources-to-deal-with-rise-in-child-refugees">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ugandan president Yoweri Museveni sworn in for fifth term</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/uganda-president-yoweri-museveni-sworn-in-fifth-term</link>
      <description><p>Representatives from Europe and North America walk out of ceremony in protest at presence of Sudanese leader</p><p>Yoweri Museveni has been sworn in for his fifth term as Uganda’s president but representatives from Europe and North America walked out of the ceremony over the attendance of the Sudanese president who is wanted on genocide charges.</p><p>Museveni, 71, was inaugurated in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, in a ceremony attended by African dignitaries including the Zimbabwean president, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/robert-mugabe">Robert Mugabe</a>, the president of South Africa, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/zuma">Jacob Zuma</a>, and <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/omar-al-bashir">Omar al-Bashir</a>, the president of Sudan. Tribal dancers entertained the crowd and Ugandan military aircraft, including Russian-made fighter jets, performed an airshow.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/uganda-president-yoweri-museveni-sworn-in-fifth-term">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/court-rejects-request-by-same-sex-indian-couple-to-remain-in-uk</link>
      <description><p>Women lose case despite fact their relationship will not be legally recognised in south Asian country</p><p>A married lesbian couple from India who have lived legally in the UK for many years have had their request to continue living in Britain rejected despite the fact their relationship will not be legally recognised in the south Asian country.</p><p>Judges at the court of appeal rejected their application to remain in the UK on Thursday.     <item>
      <title>Story of cities #41: Soul City's failed bid to build a black-run suburbia for America</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/12/story-cities-soul-city-floyd-mckissick-north-carolina-black-run-suburbia</link>
      <description><p>Civil rights activist Floyd McKissick dreamed of a southern utopia where the racially integrated community would be planned and managed by African Americans. Although the city was never completed, some traces remain</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/series/the-story-of-cities">Read more articles in the series here</a><br></li></ul><p>At first glance, this North Carolina town would have looked much like the thousands of others that were built across America’s vast countryside in the decades following the second world war. It would have consisted of single family homes on curvilinear streets within walking distance of manmade lakes, shopping centres and industry. In short, a 1970s vision of suburbia.<br></p><p>One key factor would have made this town different, however. The self-contained, racially integrated community would be planned, developed and managed by black people. Those black foundations would be celebrated in the town’s name: Soul City.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/12/story-cities-soul-city-floyd-mckissick-north-carolina-black-run-suburbia">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>One small step for Amman: could a viral video shake up Jordan's stifled capital?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/11/amman-viral-video-jordan-gate-project</link>
      <description><p>An architect’s video outlining ambitious proposals for Amman’s biggest urban failure, the Jordan Gate Project, has gone viral. Has previous apathy towards the city’s lack of community life now turned into a hunger for public space? </p><p>Architect Hanna Salameh is blunt about how his city is different from many others. “We have no concept of sidewalks,” he says. “We really see them as something you cross over to get to your car. I think that’s why so many people throw trash on the sidewalks – we have no connection to our streets. You don’t walk there and you don’t see it as yours.”</p><p>Instead, the streets of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2008/apr/20/jordan.hotels">Jordanian capital</a> are something else entirely: slow-moving strips of metallic colour, car roofs gleaming beneath fast food drive-thru signs and glass-fronted malls in interminable gridlock. If Amman was built for cars, it sometimes seems incapable of dealing with them.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/11/amman-viral-video-jordan-gate-project">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Story of cities #40: how a village had to die so Hamburg's port could survive</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/11/story-cities-altenwerder-hamburg-germany-port</link>
      <description><p>In the 60s Hamburg officials planned to demolish a fishing village to make space for a new container terminal. As port cities struggle to keep up with an ever-changing industry, how will Hamburg face the challenges of the next generation?</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/series/the-story-of-cities">Read more articles in the series here</a><br></li></ul><p>One morning in the late 80s, a pick-up truck full of sinister looking men came to a halt in front of Heinz Oestmann’s house in Altenwerder, a historic fishing village on the outer edges of Hamburg’s port. Oestmann, a fisherman and lifelong Altenwerder resident, could make out a pile of crowbars, wooden slats and gardening tools on the truck’s loading area – “all manner of objects to break things with,” he later <a href="http://www.amazon.de/HEINZ-OESTMANN-Geschichte-Deutschland-Denzlinger/dp/B010IKB8KC/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1460984304&amp;sr=8-2&amp;keywords=heinz+oestmann">recalled in his memoir</a>.</p><p>From their bedroom window, Oestmann and his wife watched as a bespectacled man from the city council got out of the truck to inspect the property. When the fisherman tried to confront the official, he got no response. Eventually, Oestmann took a swing. The man from the council landed on his backside, his glasses snapped in two.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/11/story-cities-altenwerder-hamburg-germany-port">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The great leap upward: China's Pearl River Delta, then and now</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/10/china-pearl-river-delta-then-and-now-photographs</link>
      <description><p>The Pearl River Delta has witnessed the most rapid urban expansion in human history – a predominantly agricultural region transformed into the world’s largest continuous city. By revisiting the sites of rare archive images of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Guangzhou and Macau from the 1940s through 1990s, our photographers have documented this staggering change</p><p>The region where the Pearl River flows into the South China Sea has seen some of the most rapid urban expansion in human history over the past few decades – transforming what was mostly agricultural land in 1979 into what is the manufacturing heartland of a global economic superpower today.</p><p>In 2008, China announced plans to mesh Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Dongguan, Zhaoqing, Foshan, Huizhou, Jiangmen, Zhongshan and Zhuhai into a single megacity. A series of massive infrastructure projects are under way to merge transport, energy, water and telecoms networks across the nine cities. Development has been relentless, and the World Bank recently named the Pearl River Delta as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/2015/jan/28/china-pearl-river-delta-overtake-tokyo-world-largest-megacity-urban-area">the biggest urban area in the world</a> in terms of population and geographical size.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/10/china-pearl-river-delta-then-and-now-photographs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Story of cities #39: Shenzhen – from rural village to the world's largest megalopolis</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/10/story-of-cities-39-shenzhen-from-rural-village-to-the-worlds-largest-megalopolis</link>
      <description><p>When Leo Houng arrived in Shenzhen in 1974, it was an unremarkable Chinese settlement that ‘smelled of countryside’. Since then, he has witnessed the city rise up at a bewildering rate – with little regard for the families caught in its path</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/10/china-pearl-river-delta-then-and-now-photographs">China’s Pearl River Delta, then and now</a></li></ul><p>“It should be here somewhere,” says Leo Houng, a retired cello player with the <a href="http://www.hkphil.org/eng/home/index.jsp">Hong Kong Philharmonic</a>. We are in a tangle of small streets in central <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/2014/jun/13/inside-shenzen-china-silicon-valley-tech-nirvana-pearl-river">Shenzhen</a>, just next to Lao Jie underground station. Lao Jie (“Old Street”) has existed for decades, which is more than can be said for most of Shenzhen. <br></p><p>When Houng stayed here in 1974 on his way to Hong Kong, Old Street was pretty much the only road around – with just a few lanes leading off it, dotted with simple restaurants and a handful of small shops. From there, unpaved alleys soon merged with the surrounding open countryside – an unimaginable landscape from today’s suffocating vantage point. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/10/story-of-cities-39-shenzhen-from-rural-village-to-the-worlds-largest-megalopolis">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Story of cities #38: Vancouver dumps its freeway plan for a more beautiful future</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/09/story-cities-38-vancouver-canada-freeway-protest-liveable-city</link>
      <description><p>In the 1960s, Vancouver’s historic downtown was at risk of being razed for modern road projects – only for an extraordinary protest movement to turn the tide, helping transform it into one of North America’s most ‘liveable’ cities</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/series/the-story-of-cities">Read more articles in the series here</a></li></ul><p>Half a century on, Shirley Chan can still picture the freeway that would have destroyed her old neighbourhood. “Three storeys high; eight or 10 lanes of traffic … you can imagine the dead zone along here,” she says, indicating with a sweep of her arm the swathe it would have cut through Chinatown and across Vancouver’s historic downtown east side.</p><p>In the 1960s, Chinatown was a vibrant, messy place. The sidewalks spilled over with fishmongers and fruit sellers. There were mom-and-pop grocery stores, benevolent societies, dim sum places, gambling parlours – even the alleyways had restaurants.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/09/story-cities-38-vancouver-canada-freeway-protest-liveable-city">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Story of cities #37: how radical ideas turned Curitiba into Brazil's 'green capital'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/06/story-of-cities-37-mayor-jaime-lerner-curitiba-brazil-green-capital-global-icon</link>
      <description><p>As an architect and mayor, Jaime Lerner led the movement that transformed Curitiba into an environmentally friendly ‘laboratory for urban planning’. The secret? ‘We had to work fast to avoid our own bureaucracy’</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/series/the-story-of-cities">Read more articles in the series here</a><br></li></ul><p>In the late 1960s, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/2014/dec/01/iconic-origins-brazil-capital-city-brasilia-picturing-place">Brasília</a> cast a long shadow across Brazil. Built from scratch in just four years, the city was a symbol of modern, rational, functional planning. “President Kubitschek wanted to build a new capital,” architect <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/oscar-niemeyer">Oscar Niemeyer</a> said in a <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20632277">BBC interview</a>. “He wanted a city that would represent Brazil. So I dedicated myself to finding a new solution, something that would attract attention.”</p><p>Niemeyer, along with the architect <a href="http://www.archdaily.com/tag/lucio-costa">Lúcio Costa</a>, designed the city to look like a bird in flight – a network of highways in the wings, and the administrative offices in its head. Among political elites, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/1988/01/03/arts/brasilia-a-city-of-the-future-grapples-with-a-troubled-present.html">if not all architecture critics</a>, Brasília was viewed as a triumph over Brazil’s urban chaos.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/06/story-of-cities-37-mayor-jaime-lerner-curitiba-brazil-green-capital-global-icon">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Refugees urge Kenyan leaders to rethink closure of Dadaab camp</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/refugees-urge-kenyan-leaders-to-rethink-closure-of-dadaab-camp</link>
      <description><p>Residents in world’s biggest refugee camp, some of whom have lived there for decades, tell of their sadness at decision</p><p> Residents of the world’s biggest refugee camp have called on the Kenyan government to reverse plans to close the settlement, saying proposals for forced returns of Somalis to their war-torn country would amount to a mass death sentence.<br></p><p>Abdullahi Aden Hassan, a father of nine who was one of the first to arrive in the Dadaab camp fleeing the civil war in Somalia in 1992, told the Guardian refugees had received the news, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/kenya-close-worlds-biggest-refugee-camp-dadaab">confirmed this week</a>, with shock.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/refugees-urge-kenyan-leaders-to-rethink-closure-of-dadaab-camp">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dentro de La Ciudad de las Mujeres en Colombia – podcast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/audio/2016/may/12/dentro-de-la-ciudad-de-las-mujeres-en-colombia-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Kary Stewart visita La Ciudad de las Mujeres en Turbaco, a las afueras de Cartagena, en el norte de Colombia</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/audio/2016/apr/20/inside-colombia-city-of-women-podcast-ciudad-de-las-mujeres">Inside Colombia’s City of Women – podcast in English</a></li></ul><p>Kary Stewart visita La Ciudad de las Mujeres en Turbaco, a las afueras de Cartagena, en el norte de Colombia. En 1999, la abogada Patricia Guerrero fundó La Liga de Mujeres Desplazadas para apoyar a las mujeres que sufrieron el desplazamiento forzado, la violencia sexual y el asesinato de sus seres queridos durante los largos años del conflicto en Colombia.</p><p>Como parte de su trabajo con la liga, Guerrero se puso a recaudar fondos para una ciudad de casas construidas por y para mujeres desplazadas. En 2007, la Ciudad de las Mujeres se finalizó su construcción. Hoy día, el barrio aloja a casi 500 personas y cuenta con sus propias escuelas y algunas tiendas informales – todas construidas por las mujeres.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/audio/2016/may/12/dentro-de-la-ciudad-de-las-mujeres-en-colombia-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Uganda chooses Tanzania over Kenya for oil pipeline route</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/uganda-chooses-tanzania-over-kenya-for-oil-pipeline-route</link>
      <description><p>Kampala’s decision a blow for Kenya’s oil ambitions in eastern Africa, although presidents say they will continue to work together on oil projects </p><p>Uganda is to route its oil exports through Tanzania after a report found the country was a cheaper and more secure option than its other east African neighbour Kenya.</p><p>Uganda is to use Tanga, a seaport city about 200km north of Dar es Salaam, to export its crude oil, rather than Lamu in Kenya.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/uganda-chooses-tanzania-over-kenya-for-oil-pipeline-route">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Air pollution health timebomb poses a major threat to development</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/air-pollution-health-timebomb-poses-a-major-threat-to-development-who</link>
      <description><p>A World Health Organisation report shows little escape from poisoned air in poorer countries, resulting in 3 million premature deaths worldwide a year<br></p><p> Countries are finding that the urban economic development to which they aspire brings poisoned air, ill-health, massive costs, a low quality of life and, probably, an early death for a very great many people.</p><p>That is the stark conclusion from a reading of the <a href="http://www.who.int/phe/en/">new database of outdoor air quality</a> from the World Health Organisation (WHO), for 3,000 of the world’s cities. While millions of people in rich countries suffer the cancers, heart and respiratory diseases that air pollution brings, the levels of air pollution in many Asian and African cities are said to be five or even 10 times worse.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/air-pollution-health-timebomb-poses-a-major-threat-to-development-who">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'The Central African Republic must be built from scratch'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/central-african-republic-must-be-built-from-scratch-francois-hollande-country-divided</link>
      <description><p>As François Hollande heads to CAR this week, he will find a country divided by religion and where violence among its people is horrifyingly normal </p><p>The Gbaya Ndombia maternity clinic in Bangui epitomises the ambiguity that characterises life in Central African Republic: this launchpad for new life doubles as a trauma centre for gunshot and grenade injuries.</p><p>The midwives have learned to triage patients into black (dead), red/yellow (serious), and green. They have learned how to stabilise people who have been stabbed, or lost limbs because of explosions. And they have learned how to stay calm if there are angry people at the gate, sometimes firing guns in the air.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/central-african-republic-must-be-built-from-scratch-francois-hollande-country-divided">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Banning alcohol to protect girls? India is missing the mark | Pauline Oosterhoff</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/banning-alcohol-to-protect-girls-india-is-missing-the-mark</link>
      <description><p>By debating prohibition ahead of state elections, Tamil Nadu is concealing the real issue: that gender and caste discrimination are endemic in India</p><p>Every morning, many of the young women in a village in Dindigul district, in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, head to work in the cotton mills, part of the textile industry in this state that provides vital jobs in poorer communities.</p><p>The girls often work double shifts in unventilated factories, breathing in dust up to 16 hours a day. Often their meagre salary is paid directly to the head of their family or goes straight into dowry schemes that <a href="http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/breaking-caste/in-parts-of-india-dowry-schemes-are-used-to-lure-girls-to-bonded-labour/article6781476/">lure girls to bonded labour</a>. Some girls, many of them underage, never see a rupee of it.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/banning-alcohol-to-protect-girls-india-is-missing-the-mark">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Finish line far out of sight in Nigeria's race to beat corruption | Oluseun Onigbinde</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/11/nigeria-corruption-president-muhammadu-buhari-withholding-information</link>
      <description><p>President Muhammadu Buhari needs to send the elite the message that withholding information is as corrupt as stealing money</p><p>President Muhammadu Buhari’s first foreign trip was a symbolic one. He crossed the border to Niger, where his counterpart, Mahamadou Issoufou, <a href="http://www.thescoopng.com/check-out-buharis-new-horse-and-the-governors-who-joined-him-on-his-first-foreign-trip-photos/">gave Buhari a horse</a>. It seemed an appropriate present for a leader who, since taking the reins of government, has been riding roughshod over some entrenched self-interests in the Nigerian state. </p><p>Since then, Buhari has kept an eagle eye on security contracts through the presidential committee, <a href="http://www.channelstv.com/2016/03/24/nsa-fund-scandal-presidential-committee-indicts-over-300-contractors/">indicting more than 300 companies</a> and recovering $35m (£24m) stashed away by the elite. He has started reviewing deals for any signs of money laundering, with bank chiefs already quizzed over opaque agreements fronted on behalf of politicians. Nigeria’s <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-34973872">ex-national security adviser</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/07/nigeria-former-defence-chief-alex-badeh-denies-10m-fraud-charges">former defence chief</a>, <a href="http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/top-news/196241-efcc-arrests-pdp-spokesperson-olisa-metuh-over-alleged-corruption-2.html">opposition party leaders</a> and some bank chiefs have been investigated by the economic and financial crimes commission. They deny any wrongdoing.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/11/nigeria-corruption-president-muhammadu-buhari-withholding-information">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Baby and toddlers among 149 dead at Nigerian military prison, says Amnesty</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/11/baby-and-toddlers-among-149-dead-at-nigerian-military-prison-says-amnesty</link>
      <description><p>Amnesty estimates that 149 people have died this year at the Giwa barracks in Maiduguri, and cites evidence of overcrowding, lack of sanitation and executions</p><p>At least 149 people, including a five-month-old baby and several toddlers, have died this year after being held in appalling conditions at <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/03/nigeria-army-countless-acts-torture-8000-deaths-amnesty-boko-haram">a notorious Nigerian military detention centre</a>, according to <a href="https://www.amnesty.org/en/">Amnesty International</a>.</p><p>A report from the group estimates that more than 1,200 people are detained without access to justice or the outside world at the Giwa barracks in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/28/-sp-maiduguri-nigeria-boko-haram-future">Maiduguri, north-eastern Nigeria</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/11/baby-and-toddlers-among-149-dead-at-nigerian-military-prison-says-amnesty">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Angela Merkel is suddenly looking politically mortal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2016/may/12/angela-merkel-suddenly-looking-politically-mortal</link>
      <description><p>Will the German chancellor survive to serve another term? Should she?</p><p>Europe’s most important politician <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/10/iain-duncan-smith-cameron-let-germans-veto-emergency-brake">took a bit of a pasting from the Brexit camp this week</a> for allegedly throwing her weight around in David Cameron’s company. She has had a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/12/angela-merkel-elections-refugee-crisis-far-right">rough few months</a> since the Syrian refugee crisis hit Germany and is suddenly looking politically mortal. But does Angela Merkel deserve it? </p><p>Yes and mostly no. In these turbulent times we may miss her quietly steady hand when it’s no longer there to hold. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2016/may/12/angela-merkel-suddenly-looking-politically-mortal">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>What do migrants think about ONS immigration figures?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/what-do-migrants-think-about-ons-immigration-figures</link>
      <description><p>New figures from the UK’s statistics agency have raised concerns that the government has underestimated the number of people entering the country</p><p>Today, <a href="https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/internationalmigration/articles/noteonthedifferencebetweennationalinsurancenumberregistrationsandtheestimateoflongterminternationalmigration/2016#introduction">analysis from the Office of National Statistics (ONS) explores</a> whether or not the UK’s official migration statistics have underestimated the number of people entering the country.</p><p>It finds a big gap between official figures (which suggest 257,000 migrants came to the UK between September 2014 and 2015) and the number of EU migrants registering for National Insurance numbers (630,000 over the same period). <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/what-do-migrants-think-about-ons-immigration-figures">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>West Virginia victory adds 11 delegates for Clinton and 16 for Sanders, who would need 86% of those remaining to win Democratic nomination</p><p>Tuesday’s primaries in West Virginia and Nebraska were never going to be a huge event in the electoral calendar. The contests only had a total of 107 delegates available – 37 for the Democrats and 34 for the Republicans in West Virginia, and 36 in Nebraska’s Republican primary.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/barack-obama-nuclear-weapons-enola-gay-hiroshima</link>
      <description><p>The plane that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima has been assiduously kept; Barack Obama’s commitment to ‘a world without nuclear weapons’ less so</p><p>In a quiet hangar outside Washington, the Enola Gay still gleams as if the B-29 Superfortress that dropped the first atomic bomb in anger rolled off the production line yesterday.</p><p> Despite his announcing a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/10/obama-hiroshima-japan-visit-second-world-war">historic visit</a> to the site that its payload devastated in Japan, Barack Obama’s legacy as the president who would consign all such weapons to the museum looks rather more tarnished. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/barack-obama-nuclear-weapons-enola-gay-hiroshima">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Afghan and Nigerian leaderships well aware of corruption problems</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/afghan-nigerian-leaderships-well-aware-corruption-problems</link>
      <description><p>Ashraf Ghani and Muhammadu Buhari have been fighting to turn around the pervasive culture in their two countries</p><p>It may have surprised <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/10/david-cameron-afghanistan-nigeria-possibly-most-corrupt-countries">David Cameron to find his comments to the Queen</a> about Nigeria and Afghanistan making headlines, but the current Afghan and Nigerian leaderships are fully aware that their countries are riddled with corruption, and have been fighting to turn around the pervasive culture since their respective elections.</p><p>No 10 is delighted that Muhammadu Buhari, Nigeria’s president, and Ashraf Ghani, the president of Afghanistan, are attending <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/04/cameron-to-propose-global-anti-corruption-agency-at-summit">a summit in London</a> specifically because they have acknowledged the fight against corruption is central to their respective countries’ economic revival.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/afghan-nigerian-leaderships-well-aware-corruption-problems">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Quiet crisis: why battle to prop up Italy's banks is vital to EU stability</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/battle-prop-up-italy-banks-eu-brexit-grexit-bad-loans</link>
      <description><p>Forget Brexit or Grexit, €360bn of bad loans within a fragmented Italian banking sector could be the biggest threat of all<br></p><p>Even a “small crisis” could trigger a chain of events that would threaten the stability of the European Union, the credit ratings agency Moody’s has said. Brexit – if the UK votes to leave the 28-nation union – or even Grexit – the departure of Greece from the eurozone – are the obvious vulnerabilities.</p><p>But some commentators believe an altogether quieter crisis should also be at the top of the worry list: Italy’s battle to prop up its debt-laden banks. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/battle-prop-up-italy-banks-eu-brexit-grexit-bad-loans">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2016/may/11/paul-ryan-republican-party-donald-trump-video</link>
      <description><p>House speaker Paul Ryan said on Wednesday that the GOP cannot ‘pretend to be unified’, and must seek real solidarity going into the November election. Ryan spoke to reporters ahead of his Thursday meeting with presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump. Ryan stunned the GOP last week when he said he <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/05/paul-ryan-declines-to-support-trump-as-republican-nominee">wasn’t ready to endorse him</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2016/may/11/paul-ryan-republican-party-donald-trump-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Bernie Sanders: 'we are in this to win the nomination' – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2016/may/11/bernie-sanders-west-virginia-win-nomination-video</link>
      <description><p>Bernie Sanders <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/10/west-virginia-primary-bernie-sanders-wins">defeated Hillary Clinton on Tuesday night</a> in West Virginia’s primary, winning voters who are deeply skeptical about the economy and signaling the difficulty Clinton may have in industrial states in the general election. The loss slows Clinton’s march to the nomination, but she is still heavily favored to become the Democratic candidate in the 8 November election</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/11/us-election-live-sanders-trump-clinton-campaign">Sanders lifted by West Virginia as Trump nears delegate majority – campaign live</a></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2016/may/11/bernie-sanders-west-virginia-win-nomination-video">Continue reading...</a></description>
